review_title: Really make a difference in kids’ lives
pros: Working here you’re really able to make a difference in kids’ lives. I wasn’t sure what I wanted to do after college, I just knew I wanted to make a difference and I can see first-hand the ways in which the work I do is directly affecting the kids I work with for the better.
cons: I maybe love what I do a little too much. I’m sure my friends would say my work/life balance has suffered since I started working here but it doesn’t bother me because I love the work I do. It brings me joy and makes me feel fulfilled.

pros: PTO is great for non-exempt employees. DEI initiatives have ability to make a great impact once they’re actually put in place. You find your people pretty quick and the support with coworkers is often what gets you through the day. There is a lot of opportunity to explore different positions within the agency, so long as you are liked by that director.
cons: I really was rooting for this organization but found very quickly that ethical violations are swept under the rug with little to no regard for how it is impacting other staff that have shown fierce loyalty and dedication to this work. The CEO has lost sight of how to lead with empathy and honesty and C-suite communication is calculated and saturated with for-profit mindset that comes across as disingenuous. Management will invite you in conversations of how we can improve the agency processes and then take full credit of good ideas, often using manipulative tactics to keep you silent. It really was a fantastic place to work, but bitter interaction with management has caused some of their best people to leave after years of dedicated work.

review_title: Changing the Views of Those Less Fortunate
job_title: Director of Marketing and Communications in Fairview Heights, IL
pros: The agency is very mission-driven. We focus on how we can help make changes for today and for the future of everyone we serve today and tomorrow. The team is a family that cares for each other, is focused on supporting each other in any way we can. Sometimes you just need to listen, but sometimes you need to help by getting your hands dirty and making a true change. No one is scared to help. The team loves a challenge and looks forward to helping with new and unusual ways to make a difference. In my opinion, the goal of the agency is not to yell from the rooftop that we helped but to watch for that small smile and twinkle in the eye of the ones we help.
cons: Sometimes the agency is too grassroots-focused. We are a large agency in the metro area, and we can make a bigger push for change. While the agency was founded in a small community, we are now a large organization with the experience to prove we are making a bigger difference for the greater good.

pros: How can working for children in need not be a wonderful blessing? Great mission on paper focused on serving children. Organization talks about looking to - and planning for - the future. Strong fiscal approaches. Individual, lower positions are good for those who can keep their heads down and just find joy in working with children.
cons: President/CEO is a walking cult of personality. He puts on a good face and says all of the right words (often invoking God and his personal calling) but in the end it's about him and his need for control, recognition and esteem. Despite leadership words to the contrary, front line workers are separated from leadership. Middle management is constrained from using their skills and expressing their ideas. Staff is beholden to senior and executive management in an unhealthy way. Staff and managers quietly work in absolute fear of senior leadership. Senior leadership utilizes an intricate web of back-channel communication to monitor staff work and communications, receiving informal reports instead of formal methods of review. Informal reporting is, misused, manipulated and misquoted for the benefit of leadership. These informal reports form the basis of review and retention instead of establishing clear expectations for job performance with objective performance reviews. This leadership by fear, intimidation and control is encouraged and purposefully cultivated by the CEO. All who resist - try to improve things or provide outside-the-box thinking - are quickly silenced.

I was at Hoyleton for a few years and in that time the turnover of upper management was astounding, what kind of message does that send to the direct care staff? To the clients? To the donors? To the vendors? The Culture of Hoyleton is you are not allowed to do your job unless you have direct approval by the CEO for items that require daily decision making.
